choices.text: Actinomyces israelii
Nocardia asteroides
Salmonella typhi
Francisella tularensis

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents to the clinic with a chronic wound on his neck that has been draining pus for several weeks. He denies any fever or significant pain. Physical examination reveals a sinus tract with yellowish granules in the discharge. He has a history of dental procedures and poor oral hygiene. A specimen from the draining material is anaerobic. Which organism is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Actinomyces israelii. 

 

Option A:

 

Actinomyces species are anaerobic or microaerophilic bacteria that commonly reside in the oral cavity and can cause cervicofacial actinomycosis, often presenting with chronic draining sinuses and sulfur granules in the discharge, which are aggregates of organisms.

 

 

Figure: Actinomycosis (painless, slow-growing, hard mass with cutaneous fistula) (arrow showing); B. Gram-positive filamentous bacilli; C. Gomori’s stained smear showing sun-ray appearance

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Nocardia asteroides - Nocardia are aerobic actinomycetes that can cause cutaneous infections but typically do not form sulfur granules.

 

Option C: Salmonella typhi - Salmonella typhi causes typhoid fever, which does not present with draining sinuses or sulfur granules.

 

Option D: Francisella tularensis - This is the causative agent of tularemia, which can cause ulceroglandular disease but does not typically produce sulfur granules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Actinomyces israelii as the likely causative agent in chronic wound infections presenting with sinus tracts and sulfur granules, particularly in individuals with a history of dental issues and poor oral hygiene

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med.Microbiology, 2e/p304

choices.text: Exogenous infection source
Branching filaments
Obligate aerobic metabolism
Produces black granules

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with several weeks of pain and swelling in his mandibular area. He reports a past dental infection which was treated with antibiotics. On physical examination, there is a firm mass in the jaw with draining sinuses. A sample from one of the sinuses reveals sulfur granules. Which of the following is the most likely characteristic of the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Branching filaments.

 

Option B:

 

Actinomyces israelii, the causative organism of actinomycosis, is known for its branching filaments which can be observed under microscopy. This is a classic presentation of actinomycosis, which typically manifests with firm mass formation, often in the jaw area, and can produce draining sinuses with sulfur granules. The organism is part of the normal flora and does not typically enter through exogenous sources, making option a incorrect. Actinomyces israelii is also an anaerobic organism, which contradicts option c. Lastly, the granules associated with Actinomyces are sulfur granules, which are yellowish in color, not black, ruling out option d.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Exogenous infection source: Actinomyces is part of the normal oral flora, so the infection is endogenous, not exogenous.

 

Option C: Obligate aerobic metabolism: Actinomyces israelii is an anaerobic bacteria, not an obligate aerobe.

 

Option D: Produces black granules: The granules produced by Actinomyces israelii are yellowish (sulfur granules), not black.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The characteristic branching filaments of Actinomyces species as the likely causative agent of chronic mandibular infections presenting with sulfur granules and draining sinuses. 

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p292, 2/e p304-305

choices.text: Enterococcus faecalis
Staphylococcus aureus
Streptococcus pneumoniae
Bacteroides fragilis

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of aortic valve replacement presents with signs of infective endocarditis. Blood cultures grow gram-positive cocci that are not completely hemolytic. Susceptibility testing indicates that the organism is resistant to penicillin, but synergistic bactericidal activity is observed when penicillin is combined with an aminoglycoside. Which organism is most likely responsible for the infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Enterococcus faecalis


Option A:

 

Enterococcus faecalis can be part of the normal flora but is known for causing endocarditis, particularly in patients with prosthetic heart valves. It is resistant to penicillin but demonstrates synergistic bactericidal activity when penicillin is combined with an aminoglycoside, a hallmark of enterococcal endocarditis treatment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Staphylococcus aureus is also a common cause of endocarditis but does not require combination therapy with penicillin and an aminoglycoside for treatment.

 

Option C: Streptococcus pneumoniae can cause pneumonia and meningitis but is not commonly associated with infective endocarditis and does not require aminoglycoside synergy.

 

Option D: Bacteroides fragilis is an anaerobic bacterium that is not typically involved in endocarditis and does not require aminoglycoside synergy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Most common agent in specific types of endocarditis

 

  • Native valve endocarditis: Staphylococcus aureus
  • Community acquired—Viridans streptococci
  • Healthcare acquired—S. Aureus
  • Prosthetic valve endocarditis: 
    • Early (occurs within 12 months of valve replacement)—Staphylococcus epidermidis (MC)
    • Late (occurs after 12 months of valve replacement)— Viridans streptococci (MC)
       
  • Endocarditis in IV drug abusers: 
    • Right sided: Staphylococcus aureus  (MC)
    • Left sided: MEnterococcus  (MC), followed by S. aureus 
       
  • Overall: Most common agent is Staphylococcus aureus 


Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p 231, 2/e p238

choices.text: O157:H7
O159:H9
O111:H8
O104:H21

questions.text: A 20-year-old man comes to the clinic with a 5-day history of severe abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea. He reports eating an undercooked hamburger at a local restaurant a week ago. A stool culture grows out Escherichia coli that does not ferment sorbitol. Which E. coli serotype is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) O157:H7.

 

Option A:

 

E. coli O157:H7 is the most commonly identified serotype associated with hemorrhagic colitis and hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS). This serotype is known to produce Shiga toxin and does not ferment sorbitol, which helps differentiate it from other E. coli serotypes. The history of eating undercooked meat is a risk factor for infection with E. coli O157:H7.

EHEC - 

 

Serotypes associated with EHEC are: O157:H7 (most common serotype). Other serotypes are rarely associated such as O26:Hll, O6, O55, O91, O103, O111 and O113.

 

EHEC is usually transmitted by contaminated food, i.e. consumption of lettuce, spinach, sprouts and undercooked ground beef. The infective dose is very low. Only few organisms ( <102 bacilli) are required to initiate the infection

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. O159:H9 - This serotype is not commonly associated with hemorrhagic colitis or HUS.

 

Option C. O111:H8 - While O111 is a Shiga toxin-producing E. coli, the correct antigen combination is O111:H8, not commonly associated with hemorrhagic colitis compared to O157:H7.

 

Option D. O104:H21 - This serotype is not commonly associated with hemorrhagic colitis or HUS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

E. coli O157:H7 as the serotype most frequently associated with hemorrhagic colitis following consumption of undercooked ground beef.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p304, 2/e p316, Ananthanarayan 9/e p279, 10/e p285

choices.text: It typically presents as a rapidly growing mycetoma on the extremities.
It is most commonly associated with thoracic and pulmonary infections.
Detection in clinical specimens is best achieved with fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH).
The first-line treatment for the infection caused by this organism is penicillin.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents with a firm swelling of the jaw that has been progressively enlarging over several months. He reports a dull ache in the area and occasional drainage of pus from small openings in the skin. Examination reveals a woody-hard, non-tender mass with several draining sinuses on the left side of the jaw. Histopathological examination of the exudate reveals filamentous organisms that are not acid-fast. What is the most accurate statement regarding the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The first-line treatment for the infection caused by this organism is penicillin.

 

Option D:

 

Actinomyces israelii is most commonly associated with cervicofacial actinomycosis and is treated with penicillin. The clinical scenario described is classic for cervicofacial actinomycosis, often referred to as "lumpy jaw."

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: It typically presents as a rapidly growing mycetoma on the extremities - This is incorrect. Actinomycosis usually presents with slow-growing masses and is not typical for actinomycetoma, which is caused by a different group of organisms.

 

Option B: It is most commonly associated with thoracic and pulmonary infections - This is incorrect. While Actinomyces can cause thoracic and pulmonary infections, the most common presentation is cervicofacial.

 

Option C: Detection in clinical specimens is best achieved with fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) - This is incorrect. While FISH can be used for detection, it is not the standard or most common method for diagnosing Actinomyces.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med Microbiology 1/e p293, 2/e p304-305

choices.text: Trichomonas vaginalis, indicating a protozoan infection
Candida species, suggestive of a yeast infection
Herpes simplex virus Type II, indicative of a viral infection
Actinomyces species, associated with IUD use

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents for her routine gynecological examination. She has an intrauterine device (IUD) for contraception and reports no significant medical history. On examination, her Pap smear reveals small clusters of bacteria associated with squamous cells, without any signs of cellular atypia or viral cytopathic effects.(see figure). There are no protozoans or yeast cells identified. Given this finding, which organism is most likely present on the Pap smear?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Actinomyces species, associated with IUD use. 

 

Option D:

 

Actinomyces species can be part of the normal flora but are also known to cause infections in the setting of IUD use. Their presence on a Pap smear in a patient with an IUD is indicative of actinomycosis, which does not necessarily warrant the removal of the IUD or treatment unless symptomatic infection is present.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Trichomonas vaginalis - This protozoan infection typically shows flagellated protozoans on wet mount and not on a Pap smear.

 

Option B: Candida species - Candida yeast infections are usually identified on Pap smears by the presence of pseudohyphae or budding yeasts.

 

Option C: Herpes simplex virus Type II - Herpes infection is characterized by the presence of multinucleated giant cells and cells with ground-glass nuclei, which are not described in the presented scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of small bacterial clusters associated with squamous cells on a Pap smear in a woman with an IUD is indicative of Actinomyces species. Actinomyces are bacteria that can be associated with long-term IUD use and can lead to actinomycosis, a rare but potentially serious infection. This finding warrants further investigation and possibly the removal of the IUD.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology/p292-93

choices.text: Both can exist as normal flora in the human body and cause opportunistic infections.
Both are strict anaerobes and commonly associated with dental abscesses.
Both organisms exhibit acid-fastness due to the presence of mycolic acids in their cell walls.
Infections caused by these organisms are exclusively seen in immunocompromised hosts.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presents with a cough and weight loss. A chest CT scan shows a cavitary lesion in the right upper lobe. Sputum culture grows branching filamentous organisms. Which of the following statements is accurate regarding the characteristics of the organisms that might be isolated from this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both can exist as normal flora in the human body and cause opportunistic infections.  

 

Option A:

 

Actinomyces is part of the normal flora of the oropharynx, gastrointestinal tract, and female genital tract and can cause opportunistic infections if the mucosal barrier is disrupted. Nocardia, while not typically part of the normal flora, can cause opportunistic infections primarily in immunocompromised patients but also in immunocompetent hosts, especially pulmonary nocardiosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Both are strict anaerobes and commonly associated with dental abscesses - Nocardia is an obligate aerobe, not an anaerobe, and while Actinomyces can cause dental abscesses, Nocardia typically does not.

 

Option C: Both organisms exhibit acid-fastness due to the presence of mycolic acids in their cell walls -  Nocardia exhibits partial acid-fastness due to the presence of mycolic acids, but Actinomyces does not.

 

Option D: Infections caused by these organisms are exclusively seen in immunocompromised hosts - Actinomyces can cause infection in both immunocompetent and immunocompromised hosts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry's Essentials of Medical Microbiology/p292, 2/e p304-305

choices.text: Actinomyces israelii, associated with chronic infection with sulfur granules
Group A Streptococcus, commonly implicated in pharyngitis and rheumatic fever
Neisseria meningitidis, associated with petechial rashes and meningococcemia
Corynebacterium diphtheriae, known for causing diphtheria with pseudomembrane formation

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with acute onset of a high fever, a sore throat, and difficulty swallowing. Examination reveals a grayish-white membrane on her tonsils and pharynx. Which of the following organisms is most likely to be recovered from the pharyngeal membrane of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Corynebacterium diphtheriae, known for causing diphtheria with pseudomembrane formation. 

 

Option D:

 

The clinical presentation of a grayish-white membrane in the throat is highly suggestive of diphtheria, which is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae. This organism can be recovered from the pharyngeal membrane.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Actinomyces israelii - This organism causes chronic granulomatous infections and is not typically associated with acute pharyngitis and pseudomembrane formation.

 

Option B: Group A Streptococcus - While this bacterium can cause pharyngitis, it does not produce the classic pseudomembrane associated with diphtheria.

 

Option C: Neisseria meningitidis - This organism is associated with meningococcemia and a petechial rash, not pseudomembrane formation in the throat.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corynebacterium diphtheriae as the causative agent of diphtheria, which presents with a characteristic pseudomembrane in the throat, and differentiate it from other organisms that cause pharyngitis or systemic infections.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology1/e p293,225,238,246, 2/e p304-305
